description: As of the evening of  March 31, Montenegro imposed a curfew: All individuals are prohibited from leaving their residence between 19:00 and 05:00 on weekdays, and between 13:00 on Saturday and 05:00 on Monday. Exemptions will be made for those providing essential public services. Additionally, authorities issued a ban on gatherings in residential buildings of persons who are not members of the same household. All sports and recreational activities in public spaces have also been barred.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Montenegrin authorities announced on Tuesday, April 21, that the current nationwide curfew would be shortened as coronavirus disease (COVID-19) lockdown measures begin to ease following a decrease in confirmed cases. The new curfew is now in effect between the hours of 23:00 and 05:00 (local time) on weekdays.

description: On April 28th Montenegro Airlines have prolonged the ban on commercial air traffic from Montenegro, as well as the restriction from other countries for travel until May 15th 2020. including that date. UPDATE: On March 16th, Montenegro's state airline has suspended all flights until 22 April  but has extended the suspension of traffic until May 15, 2020.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 16th, Montenegro's state airline has suspended all flights until 22 April following government halt. All international bus and railway services have also been suspended. There is also an entry ban for cruisers and yachts to ports: Bar, Budva, Kotor, Kumbor Port – Portonovi, Tivat (Gat I and Gat II) and Zelenika, until 2 April.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On May 11, 2020 the National Coordination Body for Communicable Diseases in Montenegro  has decided to l allow personal and public transportation of passengers – but within the regions. description: Beginning March 13, Montenegro's government is publishing lists containing the personal data of self-quarantined citizens who are thought to have come into contact with the potentially deadly COVID-19 coronavirus.

On March 13, Montenegro announced additional measures to tackle the outbreak. One of them is the publishing, on the government website, of personal data, including names, of people who are self-quarantined after  possible infection from the virus.

Beginning March 13, Montenegro's government is publishing lists containing the personal data of self-quarantined citizens who are thought to have come into contact with the potentially deadly COVID-19 coronavirus. As of April 25, Montenegro's government has stopped publishing this list containing personal data of self-isolating persons.

Montenegro, from March 15, is enforcing compulsory quarantine for all Montenegrin citizens, as well as for foreigners who have permanent or temporary residence in Montenegro, who come from abroad, for a period of 14 days based on the decision of the health and sanitary inspection.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Montenegrin Ministry of Health as of March 19 has imposed a new temporary measure regarding quarantine compliance and enforcement. The Health and Sanitary Inspection and the Police Directorate are tasked to monitor activities of all persons who have been ordered a self-isolation, their household members, as well as persons who brought them from the border crossing to their place of residence.

If these persons do not act in accordance with the imposed measure, the Health Sanitary Inspection and the Police Directorate will immediately file a criminal complaint with the competent state prosecutor's office for committing a criminal offence of failing to comply with the health regulations for the control of a dangerous contagious disease, for which imprisonment of up to one year is prescribed. UPDATE: The original quarantine compliance and enforcement was indeterminate, as of March 19, strengthened in both of these fields.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Montenegrin Ministry of Health, as of March 15, adopted temporary measures to prevent the introduction into the country, suppress and prevent the transmission of new coronavirus. This resulted in the closure of: catering services in hotels (excepting registered guests), disco clubs/ bars and nightclubs/ bars, catering establishments (cafes, pubs, cafeterias, restaurants and bars, excepting catering establishments that deliver food and allow food and meals to be taken over, with a ban on the stay of guests in the facilities themselves), ban on providing shopping and catering services in shopping malls ,children's playrooms, fitness centres, casinos/ betting shops and gambling outlets.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Montenegrin businesses, from March 15, must limit the number of customers, in relation to the area of the retail outlet, so that only one consumer can be located in ten square meters of the surface of the outlet. Regardless of the surface, no more than 50 consumers can reside in a retail outlet at a time. Exceptionally for markets and bazaars, the number of customers who can be in the facility simultaneously limits up to 100 consumers.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Montenegro is enforcing on businesses, as of March 15, the obligation of responsible persons in trade establishments to provide or mark a distance, of at least two meters between persons located in front of retail outlets, at cash registers and sectors where goods are served by employees in the outlet.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Montenegro, as of March 15, makes the responsible persons in the trade establishments obligated to indicate at the entrance to the sales facility the notification of the maximum number of persons, who can be in the same facility at the same time and to organise the implementation of this measure.

description: On March 21, Montenegro announced it was banning gatherings for weddings, and only allowing funerals with immediate family members.

On March 21, Montenegro announced it was banning gatherings for weddings, and only allowing funerals with immediate family members.

From June 1, as part of the re-opening program, up to 200 people can attend all types of gatherings, both outdoors and indoors, in public places, including wedding festivities and funerals. UPDATE: This policy was ended on June 1.

On May 4, 2020 the government in Montenegro announced that  “A legal person will have to pay a fine ranging from €2.000 to €20.000 for failing to ensure practicing of physical distance measures among people in their facilities and protective equipment – face masks – for employees providing trade services, hospitality services, those working in hairdresser and beauty salons."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside public or commercial building
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
